Here's what I would rather do: Whips can latch onto something you aim with (like a bow or trident) and if that block is whip compatible, then you can use it to swing. Also whips can be used as a weapon, just aim with it and hit a mob with it. There can be a whip for every basic ore: leather, stone, gold, iron, diamond, and netherite, but also any new ones if there's any. They could also have a spike at the end (enchantment?). Anyways, I didn't want this idea to be too bland and all, just something I would have said or added.

384000490092 I like this, but I think the basic whip should be made of leather, but can be modified with shards of material (Bricks, bones, diamonds) that increase damage dealt to entities. I think also the latching should be an enchantment (Kind of like riptide on the trident). I actually made a post detailing this idea more fully, will edit with the link when it gets approved.

I think this is a good idea, and it could apply to the new goat horns as well. I think making an entirely new bow would be a bit much since there's not a lot separating a bow/crossbow from a theoretical reinforced bow/crossbow, so I'd suggest making it more of an upgrade rather than an alternative. For example, combining a bow with 2 goat horns, 1 stick, and 3 string (or 2 goat horns, 1 stick, 2 string, and maybe even 1 iron for a crossbow) would create a reinforced bow - this could apply to ores as well. That way bows/crossbows and their reinforced counterparts wouldn't be competing with each other; instead, the latter would be the next step up from the former. Horns from goats and cattle have traditionally been used (notably by the nomadic peoples of Central and Northeast Asia) to increase flexibility and power in real-life bows anyway, and it seems like it could fit naturally in the world of Minecraft, keeping with the more "medieval" setting as they say. Also, having to upgrade a normal bow/crossbow really does fit the concept of a "reinforced bow/crossbow."

[ empty, goat horn, string;

  stick,       bow,      string;

  empty, goat horn, string ]

[ goat horn, empty/iron ingot, goat horn;

    string,          crossbow,         string;

    empty,             stick,            empty ]

if you're looking for a cuurent survival friendly option, I recommend scaffolding. I like to use them for bee farms, climbing up through the bottom of a little bee hut. Ofc this works with anything if they're above the scaffolding since mobs can't sneak through them, and works for most mobs below them except climbin spider. But yea a less limited option would be nice, since they are vertical and you can't see well through them.

Gold weights more than diamonds and iron logically, but diamond sword and tools should be most valuable in all works in general, the only good use was if golden pickaxes were able to mine a lot faster than diamond pickaxe but gold is best used for crafting exclusive items. Gold in real life is less dense than iron and diamond but weights a lot more.

Definitely agree with you that there's currently very little reason to craft golden tools, other than to look cool! They need some advantage over the other materials. Perhaps there could be a new block only mineable by gold tools for example.
Great idea! It would help create darker, scarier maps!

Good idea. A bit like a sticky note but with paper. Write a formal letter, simple reminder, etc.. You know how maps are shown when placed in an item frame? Could the same be done with written notes?? That would be good for menus in cafes (roleplay).

I came up with an idea like this today for a "Letter","Note" or "Written Paper", so I found this post. The item would be similar to how Written Book/Book and Quill work, with the restriction of it being only one page long. It would come with a re-textured GUI to look like a piece of paper or a note.

What I also had in mind it being able to be pinned to the side of a wall, either with, or without an Item Frame (the latter would make sense with how Maps can be displayed), to make for a noticeboard. The "Written Paper" would have a bigger look than a regular Paper displayed in Item Frame, just like Maps do, either readable like Signs or opening up a GUI to read what is written on it.

Writing on the "Letter" would open up the GUI, with signature options and all, after then it becomes locked from further editing and becomes a "Written Paper". Reading the "Written Paper" would happen by either holding it in hand, or better: opening up a readable GUI by clicking on it when it's displayed/pinned on the Item Frame or wall; (however, Maps displayed in Item Frame are rotated by clicking on them which wouldn't make sense in this case...) This would mean you don't need to take it off and put it back on every time you want to read it. The item would be popped out from it's place by punching on it, just like any displayed item.

Crafting recipe for it could be logically Paper, Ink Sac and Feather.

This would be a nice addition using ingredients and mechanics already in game, and would be great for adventuring and roleplay purposes.

I had this idea last night when battling endless hoards of drowned.

Armour made from rotten flesh (as the original post above suggests) would turn zombies into neutral mobs. Essentially they would ignore you, at the expense of being more vulnerable to other aggressive mobs.

I would also like rotten flesh armour to make the drowned (essentially underwater zombies) neutral mobs. However, the downside is that rotten flesh armour would disintegrate more quickly when underwater hence the need to create more of it the longer spent in the depths.
maybe you could give it up to 4 arms
A lot of auto crafting ideas suggest using redstone signals. I like this one because it runs on a fuel source, and therefore adds a wait time and cost to automation.
Perhaps treat them as kelp in that they would need to be dried in a furnace and then crafted into a compressed dried leaf block before it could be used as a fairly effective fuel.

I think that this could make swimming much easier. It could also differentiate from the Night Potion. Currently, if you're above the water line with a Night Potion, you can see into the water, which really doesn't make sense, seeing as how it's a Night Potion. That aspect of the Night Potion could be taken away, and this could be added, letting you see into water when above and under water. This could make fighting, building, and mining underwater much better, making it easier to do all of those and could encourage new mobs, ores, exploration, and structures underwater. The only thing I would change, is instead of making the sight infinite (which would crash whatever console you're on), just making it go only as far as sight on land.

Night vision isn't necessarily a night potion, it's only called that because it's useful and mostly used in the night. it is used in all kinds of dark places. Conduits make it easier to see in the water too.
